poem:
### On the Tube 

In the stutter of travel,  
grace trips over hurry—  
a farewell rush,  
clattering softly into  
the blur of steel and echo.  
Between strangers' silence,  
a wobble finds no elegance,  
but in the heart's  
quiet chambers,  
stories unfold,  
even as the doors close  
on unwritten pages.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Blind date: ‘My rushing to make the tube doors felt rather shabby, definitely not chic’ Tom on Francoise What were you hoping for?The unexpected. First impressions?Elegant. What did you talk about?Family, in the Larkin sense, and past lives. Service, care, presence and community. Places we’ve been, places to go. Books, gardens and food. Most awkward moment?An ungracious wobble on the tube rushing to make the doors as we parted. A poor closing on my part.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Blind date: ‘My rushing to make the tube doors felt rather shabby, definitely not chic’ Tom on Francoise What were you hoping for?The unexpected. First impressions?Elegant. What did you talk about?Family, in the Larkin sense, and past lives. Service, care, presence and community. Places we’ve been, places to go. Books, gardens and food. Most awkward moment?An ungracious wobble on the tube rushing to make the doors as we parted. A poor closing on my part.
